facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 237 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 237 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 7, 1966 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Misc. Petition No. 1621 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 7, 1966 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Misc. Petition No. 1621 of 1966.

facts.text: Supreme Court passed order on 14th December 1966.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, by special leave, we have already passed the order on 14th December, 1966, and we now indicate our reasons for that order.

facts.text: Appellant was born on April 6, 1938, at Suryapet in Nalgonda District, Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was born on. April 6, 1938, at Suryapet in Nalgonda District, Andhra Pradesh, and was educated and brought up there until the year 1951.

facts.text: Appellant educated and brought up in Suryapet until 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was born on. April 6, 1938, at Suryapet in Nalgonda District, Andhra Pradesh, and was educated and brought up there until the year 1951.

facts.text: Appellant's father died in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: His father died in 1947.

facts.text: Appellant left for Pakistan in August 1951.

anchor.surface_text: After the partition of India and the enforcement of the Constitution, the appellant, in August 1951, left for Pakistan where he stayed until 1955.

facts.text: Appellant stayed in Pakistan until 1955.

anchor.surface_text: After the partition of India and the enforcement of the Constitution, the appellant, in August 1951, left for Pakistan where he stayed until 1955.

facts.text: Appellant returned to India in 1955 on a passport obtained from Pakistan Government as Pakistani citizen with visa from Indian Government.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955, he returned to India on a passport obtained from the Pakistan Government as a Pakistani citizen with a visa from the Indian Government.

facts.text: Appellant continued to stay in India after expiry of visa.

anchor.surface_text: Even after the expiry of the visa, he continued to stay in India, but in August, 1963, he was deported to Pakistan.

facts.text: Appellant deported to Pakistan in August 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Even after the expiry of the visa, he continued to stay in India, but in August, 1963, he was deported to Pakistan.

facts.text: Appellant came to India again with passport dated 4th December 1963 issued by Pakistan Government and visa dated 20th January 1964 from Indian High Commission, arrived on 5th February 1964.

anchor.surface_text: He came again to India with a passport dated 4th December, 1963 issued by the Pakistan Government with a visa from the Indian High Commission dated 20th January, 1964. Be arrived in India on 5th February, 1964.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 challenging deportation order, allowed by Andhra Pradesh High Court, deportation quashed on ground no determination of Pakistani citizenship under s.9 Citizenship Act.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the question of deportation of the appellant by the Indian Government arose, and thereupon, the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the order of deportation made by the Government of India. The petition was allowed by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh and the order of deportation was quashed on the ground that there had been no determination that the appellant had acquired Pakistani citizenship under s. 9 of the Citizenship Act by the Indian Government.

facts.text: Government issued notice to appellant on 19th March 1965 through Government of Andhra Pradesh to submit representation within one month.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Government took up the question of determining the nationality of the appellant, and a notice was issued to the appellant on 19th March, 1965 through the Government of Andhra Pradesh asking the appellant, within one month from the date of the service of the notice on him, to submit to the Government of Andhra Pradesh for onward transmission to consideration of the Central Government any representation that the appellant might wish to make.

facts.text: Appellant made two representations, later one in May 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made two representations. The later of the two representations was sent by him in the month of May, 1965.

facts.text: Government of India issued order on 18th August 1965 holding appellant voluntarily acquired citizenship of Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India, on 18th August, 1965, issued an order holding that the appellant had voluntarily acquired the citizenship of Pakistan.

facts.text: Appellant challenged the August 1965 order by another Art. 226 petition before Andhra Pradesh High Court, which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged this order by another petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, and that petition was dismissed by the order under appeal before us.

facts.text: It was not disputed that Government of India competent under s.9(2) Citizenship Act to determine if appellant acquired Pakistani citizenship.

anchor.surface_text: It was not disputed, as it could not be disputed in this case, that the Government of India was competent under s. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act, 1955 to determine whether the appellant had acquired the citizenship of Pakistan.

facts.text: Appellant had gone to Pakistan in August 1951 after enforcement of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the appellant had gone to Pakistan in August 1951 after the enforcement of the Constitution.

facts.text: Government considered representations of appellant and principles of evidence in Schedule III of Citizenship Rules before order.

anchor.surface_text: The order dated 18th August, 1965 passed by the Government of India, shows that, before giving its decision, the Government considered the cause shown by the appellant and gave due regard to the principles of evidence contained in Schedule III of the Citizenship Rules, 1956 in accordance with Rule 30 thereof.

facts.text: Appellant urged no adequate opportunity to put forward case before Government decision.

anchor.surface_text: This order has been challenged on behalf of the appellant on the ground that the appellant was not given an adequate opportunity of putting forward his case before the Government of India gave its decision on 18th August, 1965 holding that the appellant had voluntarily acquired the citizenship of Pakistan.

facts.text: Appellant did not raise plea that he did not voluntarily obtain passports from Pakistan in 1955 and 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Though, in both those representations, he urged that he had not voluntarily acquired the citizenship of Pakistan, he did not at any stage raise any plea that he had not voluntarily acquired the passports on the basis of which he came to India on the two occasions in 1955 and 1964.

facts.text: Appellant was minor when went to Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, though the appellant did put forward a plea that when he went to Pakistan, he was a minor,

facts.text: Appellant did not urge he did not go to Pakistan voluntarily or was compelled or abducted.

anchor.surface_text: it was never urged on his behalf that he had not gone to Pakistan voluntarily, or that he had left because he was compelled by the disturbed conditions in India, or that he was taken there by abduction or against his will.

facts.text: Appellant stayed in Pakistan for four years after arrival.

anchor.surface_text: Even after arrival in Pakistan, he stayed on for a period of four years,

facts.text: No plea that appellant compelled to apply for Pakistani passport.

anchor.surface_text: Then, there was no plea that he was compelled to apply for the passport as a Pakistani citizen and did not, in fact, obtain it voluntarily.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no occasion for further enquiry by Government as paragraph 3 Schedule III Citizenship Rules applicable.

anchor.surface_text: We, however, find that, on the facts of the present case, there was no occasion for the Government of India to enter into any such enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: This order has been challenged on behalf of the appellant on the ground that the appellant was not given an adequate opportunity of putting forward his case before the Government of India gave its decision on 18th August, 1965 holding that the appellant had voluntarily acquired the citizenship of Pakistan.

concepts.interpretation: Adequate opportunity provided through notice and representations; no need for further enquiry absent specific plea.

anchor.surface_text: Proceeding further, the Court considered the circumstances which have to be taken into account in applying the provisions of paragraph 3 of Schedule III of the Citizenship Rules which raises a conclusive presumption that a citizen of India, who has obtained a passport from a foreign country on any date, has before that date voluntarily acquired citizenship of that country.

concepts.interpretation: Creates conclusive presumption of voluntary citizenship acquisition upon obtaining foreign passport, unless plea of non-voluntary obtainment raised and opportunity given to disprove.

concepts.interpretation: Applicable without further enquiry as no plea raised that passports not voluntarily obtained; appellant represented himself as Pakistani citizen.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the Government of India should have held an enquiry before arriving at this decision, and for this proposition reliance is placed on the decision of this Court in Mohd. Ayub Khan v. Commissioner of Police, Mad-ras and Another. It was held in that case that The question as to whether when and how foreign citizenship has been acquired has to be determined having regard to the rules of evidence prescribed, and termination of Indian citizenship being the consequence of voluntary acquisition of foreign citizenship, the authority has also to determine that such latter citizenship has been voluntarily acquired.

concepts.interpretation: Postulates quasi-judicial approach with due notice and reasonable opportunity; extent depends on case circumstances and pleas raised.

arguments.claim: Appellant obtained passports representing himself as Pakistani citizen triggering conclusive presumption under paragraph 3 Schedule III

anchor.surface_text: No such facts having been alleged, it is number possible for this Court to hold that the Government of India was called upon to make any detailed enquiry when the provisions of paragraph 3 of Schedule III of the Citizenship Rules, were clearly applicable, because the appellant had obtained passports in Pakistan representing himself to be a Pakistani citizen.

holdings.text: on the facts of the present case, there was no occasion for the Government of India to enter into any such enquiry

anchor.surface_text: We, however, find that, on the facts of the present case, there was no occasion for the Government of India to enter into any such enquiry. As we have mentioned earlier, the appellant made two representations to the Government of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant made representations but did not raise plea of non-voluntary acquisition of passports, no facts of compulsion, abduction or disturbed conditions alleged, stayed four years in Pakistan without explanation

holdings.text: the provisions of paragraph 3 of Schedule III of the Citizenship Rules, were clearly applicable, because the appellant had obtained passports in Pakistan representing himself to be a Pakistani citizen

anchor.surface_text: No such facts having been alleged, it is not possible for this Court to hold that the Government of India was called upon to make any detailed enquiry when the provisions of paragraph 3 of Schedule III of the Citizenship Rules, were clearly applicable, because the appellant had obtained passports in Pakistan representing himself to be a Pakistani citizen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant obtained Pakistani passports on two occasions without pleading non-voluntary obtainment, triggering conclusive presumption under para 3 Schedule III

holdings.text: It cannot, therefore, be said that, in this case, the Government of India failed to hold any enquiry which it was required to do

anchor.surface_text: No such facts having been alleged, it is not possible for this Court to hold that the Government of India was called upon to make any detailed enquiry when the provisions of paragraph 3 of Schedule III of the Citizenship Rules, were clearly applicable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scope of enquiry depends on circumstances and pleas raised; no relevant plea raised by appellant distinguishing from Mohd. Ayub Khan case

holdings.text: the order dated 18th August, 1965 passed by the Government of India does not suffer from any infirmity

anchor.surface_text: It cannot, therefore, be said that, in this case, the Government of India failed to hold any enquiry which it was required to do, and consequently, the order dated 18th August, 1965 passed by the Government of India does not suffer from any infirmity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adequate notice given, representations considered per Rule 30 and Schedule III, no further enquiry required under para 3 as no plea raised

holdings.text: the Government considered the cause shown by the appellant and gave due regard to the principles of evidence contained in Schedule III of the Citizenship Rules, 1956 in accordance with Rule 30 thereof

anchor.surface_text: It was not disputed, as it could not be disputed in this case, that the Government of India was competent under s. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act, 1955 to determine whether the appellant had acquired the citizenship of Pakistan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-Constitution migration; statutory authority not disputed

precedents.cited_proposition: Government of India should have held an enquiry before arriving at its decision holding voluntary acquisition of Pakistani citizenship, as determination requires quasi-judicial approach with notice and opportunity to rebut presumption from obtaining foreign passport under para 3 Schedule III Citizenship Rules
precedents.cited_holding: If a plea is raised by the citizen that he had not voluntarily obtained the passport, the citizen must be afforded an opportunity to prove that fact.

anchor.surface_text: We, however, find that, on the facts of the present case, there was no occasion for the Government of India to enter into any such enquiry. As we have mentioned earlier, the appellant made two representations to the Government of India.

It cannot, therefore, be said that, in this case, the Government of India failed to hold any enquiry which it was required to do, and consequently, the order dated 18th August, 1965 passed by the Government of India does number suffer from any infirmity.

edges.explanation: The holding that Government considered the cause shown by appellant addresses the issue of whether adequate opportunity was given before the decision.

anchor.surface_text: The order dated 18th August, 1965 passed by the Government of India, shows that, before giving its decision, the Government considered the cause shown by the appellant and gave due regard to the principles of evidence contained in Schedule III of the Citizenship Rules, 1956 in accordance with Rule 30 thereof.

It cannot, therefore, be said that, in this case, the Government of India failed to hold any enquiry which it was required to do, and consequently, the order dated 18th August, 1965 passed by the Government of India does number suffer from any infirmity.
